questions.text: The microsomal enzyme involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel, and proton pump inhibitors is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CYP2C19

 

Option C:

 

The cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes are a family of enzymes that play a key role in the metabolism of many drugs.

 

This is the correct answer. CYP2C19 is involved in the metabolism of clopidogrel and PPIs. Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by this enzyme, and the effectiveness of clopidogrel can be reduced by PPIs that inhibit CYP2C19.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The metabolism of clopidogrel and proton pump inhibitors primarily involves the CYP2C19 enzyme, and inhibitors of this enzyme can reduce the activation and efficacy of clopidogrel.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers: CYP3A4

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched regarding drug elimination?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Simvastatin: Glucuronide conjugation

 

Option D:

 

The elimination of drugs can occur through various pathways, including metabolism by cytochrome P450 enzymes, conjugation reactions, or transport by proteins such as p-glycoprotein.

 

This is incorrect. While simvastatin or its metabolites may undergo glucuronidation, the primary pathway for simvastatin metabolism is through CYP3A4. The clinical significance is in the potential interactions with drugs that induce or inhibit CYP3A4 which would affect the plasma levels of simvastatin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: CYP3A4: This is correct. Many calcium channel blockers are metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme.

 

Option B. Carvedilol: CYP2D6: This is correct. Carvedilol is metabolized by CYP2D6 among other enzymes.

 

Option C. Digoxin: p-glycoprotein: This is correct. Digoxin is a substrate for p-glycoprotein, which plays a role in its elimination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While simvastatin metabolites may undergo glucuronide conjugation, the primary enzyme responsible for simvastatin metabolism is CYP3A4; thus, drugs that affect CYP3A4 activity can alter simvastatin's plasma concentration.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with chronic atrial fibrillation is prescribed a drug that requires rapid attainment of therapeutic plasma concentration. Loading dose of a drug depends upon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Volume of distribution

Option A:

The loading dose of a drug is based on the volume of distribution (Vd), which relates to how extensively a drug distributes throughout the body. It is calculated by multiplying the Vd by the desired plasma concentration.

 

Loading Dose = Vd x Target Plasma Concentration

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Clearance: Incorrect for loading dose. Clearance is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time and is more relevant to determining the maintenance dose.

 

Option C. Half-life: Incorrect for loading dose. Half-life is the time taken for the plasma concentration of a drug to reduce to half its initial value and influences the dosing interval and maintenance doses rather than the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: Incorrect for loading dose. Bioavailability refers to the fraction of an administered dose that reaches systemic circulation in an active form and does not directly impact the calculation of a loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of a drug is calculated based on the volume of distribution and the desired plasma concentration to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the plasma.

choices.text: Drug is an instant release preparation
Meant for intra pulmonary use
The standards according to Indian Pharmacopoeia
Drug tested preclinically via Intraperitoneal route

questions.text: What does IP in the figure shown stands for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The standards according to Indian Pharmacopoeia

 

Option C:

 

"Indian Pharmacopoeia" is a set of guidelines by the Government of India which sets standards for all drugs that are manufactured, sold, and consumed in India. "IP" indicates that the drug meets these standards.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: "Instant release preparation" refers to the formulation of the drug that affects how quickly it is released into the bloodstream; however, "IP" does not indicate this.

 

Option B: "Intra pulmonary use" suggests that the drug is to be used within the lungs, typically inhalation drugs fall under this category, but "IP" does not denote this.

 

Option D: "Intraperitoneal route" is a method of drug administration used in research, but "IP" on a drug package does not relate to this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "IP" on a medication package indicates that the drug conforms to the standards set by the Indian Pharmacopoeia.

 

  • IP stands for Indian Pharmacopoeia
  • BP: British Pharmacopoeia
  • USP: United Nations Pharmacopoeia
  • BNF: British National Formulary

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient (60 kg) is going to be treated with an experimental drug, Drug X, for an irregular heart rhythm. If the Vd is 1 L/kg and the desired steady state plasma concentration is 2.5 mg/L, which of the following is the most appropriate intravenous loading dose for Drug X?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 150 mg

 

Option A:

 

  • For IV infusion, Loading dose = (Vd) × (desired steady-state plasma concentration).
  • The Vd in this case is 1 L/kg, so for a 60 Kg person, Vd is 60 L.
  • Thus, Loading dose = 60 L × 2.5 mg/L = 150 mg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct intravenous loading dose of a drug can be calculated by multiplying the volume of distribution by the desired plasma concentration; in this case, 60 L × 2.5 mg/L = 150 mg.

choices.text: High plasma protein binding
Low ionization at physiological pH values

questions.text: All the following factors tend to increase the volume of distribution of a drug EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High plasma protein binding.

 

Option A:

 

  • When a drug binds extensively to plasma proteins, such as albumin, its ability to leave the bloodstream and distribute into other tissues is reduced. This leads to a lower Vd because a greater proportion of the drug remains confined to the plasma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Low ionization at physiological pH values: Drugs that are less ionized at physiological pH can more readily cross cell membranes since non-ionized forms are generally more lipid-soluble. This allows the drug to distribute more widely into various tissues, including those beyond the vascular compartment, thus increasing the Vd.

 

Option C. High lipid solubility: Lipid-soluble drugs can cross cell membranes more easily and can accumulate in fatty tissues. This property can lead to a larger Vd because the drug can be distributed more extensively into body tissues, particularly fat stores.

 

Option D. High tissue binding: When a drug has a high affinity for tissue binding sites, it will be sequestered in these peripheral compartments rather than remaining in the bloodstream. This sequestration in tissues increases the Vd as the drug is stored outside of the vascular system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While high lipid solubility, low ionization, and high tissue binding increase a drug's volume of distribution, high plasma protein binding generally decreases it.

choices.text: Satisfy priority health care needs of population
Should be available as a combination
Available in all doses and formulations

questions.text: Following are the criteria for Essential drugs EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Should be available as a combination

 

Option C:

 

  • This is not a criterion for an Essential Medicine. In fact, the WHO often prefers single-agent medications to fixed-dose combinations, unless the combination has proven benefits in terms of treatment outcomes, reduced pill burden, or prevention of resistance, such as in the case of certain antiretrovirals or tuberculosis treatments.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Satisfy priority health care needs of the population:

 

  • This is a core criterion for Essential Medicines. These drugs are chosen because they meet the most important healthcare needs of the majority of the population. They are selected based on the disease prevalence and public health importance.

 

Option B. Cost-effective:

 

  • Essential Medicines should be cost-effective, meaning they provide the best health benefits at the lowest cost. This does not mean they are always the cheapest available, but that their cost is justifiable by the level of benefit they provide in the context of the health system's overall budget.

 

Option D. Available in all doses and formulations:

 

  • Essential Medicines should be available in appropriate formulations that suit all age groups and populations, taking into account different dosage forms like tablets, syrups, or injectables to ensure that everyone who needs the medicine can receive it in a form that is effective and usable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Essential Medicines should address the priority health care needs, be cost-effective, and be available in appropriate formulations for the entire population, with a preference for single compounds over combinations unless there is a clear rationale for the latter.

questions.text: A 70 Kg person was started on a drug with Vd =10 L and exhibits first-order elimination kinetics.  The rate of drug clearance is calculated to be 6.93 L/hr.  It is determined that repeating the second dose when 75% of the drug is eliminated will minimize toxicity while maintaining trough levels above the minimum inhibitory concentration.  Based on these research findings, which of the following is the most appropriate dosing interval for this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 hours

 

Explanation:

 

To determine the dosing interval for this drug, we need to first calculate the half-life (t1/2) of the drug. We can use the formula:

t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd / clearance

 

where Vd is the volume of distribution and clearance is the rate of drug clearance.

Substituting the given values, we get:

t1/2 = 0.693 x 10 / 6.93 t1/2 = 1 hour

 

The time to eliminate 75% of the drug would be 2 half-lives (in 1 half-life 50 percent is eliminated and in 2 half-lives 75 percent will be eliminated) . Therefore, the time to eliminate 75% of the drug would be:

t = 2 x t1/2 = 2 x 1 = 2 hours

 

So, the appropriate dosing interval would be around 2 hours to ensure that 75% of the previous dose is eliminated before the next dose is given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a drug with first-order elimination kinetics, a dosing interval should be set based on its half-life to minimize toxicity and maintain effective drug concentrations.
